text:
It was a long road to the Supreme Court: A diagnosis with diabetes, her father’s death to alcoholism, her cousin’s overdose. 

It all began in the Bronx, in tenement housing, in a community of Puerto Rican immigrants.

transcript: This was the 1950s. You didn't leave your house in my mother's generation without your hair made up and makeup on.

caption1: Celina Sotmayor (left) and her sister
transcript: There was a sense of pride in how you look. My family's standard of living was no different than the entire neighborhood.

caption1: Christmas, circa 1958
transcript: I can't tell you how people afforded it. When I first moved to the projects, you did not walk into an apartment that wasn't clean and decent looking.

caption1: Sotomayor and her grandparents: Abuelita (right) and Gallego
transcript: My mother will tell you today that I am my grandmother's daughter.

caption1: Abuelita (center), Sotomayor's grandmother
transcript: My grandmother was the most spirited person I've ever known.

caption1: Gallego and Abuelita
transcript: She had boundless energy. Get up at the crack of dawn to make a pot of coffee for my grandfather. He drank it black and I drank it black. And we'd go out shopping. She'd come back and she'd start preparing food.

caption1: Gallego and Abuelita
transcript: And that night there would be a party.

caption1: Sotomayor's mother, Celina

Either that day or the next day blood tests were done and I was ultimately diagnosed with diabetes. It was the first time that I had seen my mother cry.

transcript: Statistically at the time, most diabetics began to experience serious complications in their 30s. And living to your 50s was considered a gift.

book_quote: I’ve lived most of my life inescapably aware that it is precious and finite. The reality of diabetes always lurked in the back on my mind, and early on I accepted the probability that I would die young.

transcript: He was enormously creative. He was a poet and loved poetry.

caption1: Sotomayor's father in the kitchen
transcript: He was a fabulous, fabulous cook. I still remember some of his dishes. I don't think anyone has ever duplicated his liver and onions for me.

I can look at photos of him and I can tell you which photos were taken before he had really started drinking a lot and which photos he was already a little gone. You can see it in his eyes. And I often wondered about what he was thinking about.

It’s really hard to live with a person who has an addiction because their obsession with their addiction becomes the obsession of the family. There's internal torture in the people who are consumed by it.
